references: Motivated by the above observations and analyses on dimensional collapse caused by data heterogeneity in federated learning, we explore how to mitigate excessive dimensional collapse.

Since dimensional collapse on the global model is inherited from local models, we propose to alleviate the problem during local training.
One natural way to achieve this is to add the following regularization term on the representations during training

-th singular value of the covariance matrix of the representations.
Essentially,
penalizes the variance among the singular values, thus discouraging the tail singular values from collapsing to
, mitigating dimensional collapse. However, this regularization term is not practical as it requires calculating all the singular values, which is computationally expensive.
Therefore, to derive a computationally-cheap training objective, we first apply the z-score normalization on all the representation vectors
. This results in the covariance matrix of
being equal to its correlation matrix (i.e., the matrix of correlation coefficients). The following proposition suggests a more convenient cost function to regularize.

.
This proposition suggests that regularizing the Frobenius norm of the correlation matrix
achieves the same effect as minimizing
. In contrast to the singular values,
To leverage this proposition, we propose a novel method,
, which regularizes the Frobenius norm of the correlation matrix of the representation vectors during local training on each client. Formally, the proposed regularization term is defined as:
is the correlation matrix of the representations. The overall objective of each local client is
is the cross entropy loss, and
. The pseudocode of our method is provided in Appendix
in mitigating dimensional collapse, we now revisit the experiments of Fig.
. We plot our results in Fig.

for both local and global models.
Figs.
encourages the tail singular values to not collapse to

, thus effectively mitigating dimensional collapse.
Moreover, as illustrated in Figs.
on local models can also be inherited by the global models.

. We partition the three benchmark datasets (CIFAR10, CIFAR100, and TinyImageNet) into

We observe that for all of the heterogeneous settings on all datasets, the highest accuracies are achieved by adding

on top of a certain baseline method.
In particular, in the strongly heterogeneous settings where

over baseline methods on all datasets.
On the other hand, for the less heterogeneous setting of

.
Such decrease in improvements is a general trend and is also observed on FedProx, FedAvgM, and MOON.
In addition, surprisingly, in the homogeneous setting of

still produces around 2% of improvements on the TinyImageNet dataset.
We conjecture that this is because TinyImageNet is much more complicated than the CIFAR datasets, and some other factors besides heterogeneity of label may cause undesirable dimensional collapse in the federated learning setup. Therefore, federated learning on TinyImageNet can benefit from
To further demonstrate the advantages of
, we apply it on FedAvg and plot how the test accuracy of the global model evolves throughout the federated learning in Fig.

.
In this figure, if we set a certain value of the testing accuracy as a threshold, we see that adding
significantly reduces the number of communication rounds needed to achieve the given threshold. This further shows that
not only improves the final performance, but also greatly boosts the communication efficiency in federated learning.

references:
’s advantage vis-à-vis some of its competitors in terms of its computational efficiency.
We compare

with some other methods that also apply additional regularization terms during local training such as FedProx and MOON.
We partition CIFAR10, CIFAR100 and TinyImageNet into
and report the total computation times required for one round of training for FedAvg, FedProx, MOON, and
. All results are produced with a NVIDIA Tesla V100 GPU. We see that
incurs a negligible computation overhead on top of the naïve FedAvg, while FedProx and MOON introduce about
additional computation cost. The advantage of

in terms of efficiency is mainly because it only involves calculating the Frobenius norm of a matrix which is extremely cheap. Indeed this regularization operates on the output representation vectors of the model, without requiring computing parameter-wise regularization like FedProx nor extra forward passes like MOON.

references: Some decorrelation regularizations such as DeCov

were proposed to improve the generalization capabilities in standard classification tasks. Both these methods operate directly on the covariance matrix of the representations instead of the correlation matrix like our proposed method—
with the existing decorrelation methods, we follow the same procedure as in
and apply DeCov and Structured-DeCov during local training. Our experiments are based on TinyImageNet and FedAvg. TinyImageNet is partitioned into
. Surprisingly, we see that unlike our

which steadily improves the baseline, adding DeCov or Structured-DeCov both degrade the performance in federated learning. We conjecture that this is because directly regularizing the covariance matrix is highly unstable, leading to undesired modification on the representations. This experiment shows that our design of regularization of the

A3.T7.table:
MobileNetV2 ResNet18 ResNet32
FedAvg 64.85 71.51 65.76
+ FedDecorr 73.06 76.54 67.21
references: In this section, we demonstrate the effectiveness of our method across different model architectures. Here, besides the MobileNetV2 used in the main paper, we also experiment on ResNet18 and ResNet32. Note that ResNet18 is the wider ResNet whose representation dimension is
and ResNet32 is the narrower ResNet whose representation dimension is
. The coefficient of the FedDecorr objective is set to be
as suggested to be a good universal value of
in the paper. The heterogeneity parameter
and we use the CIFAR10 dataset. Our results are shown in Tab.

. As can be seen, FedDecorr yields consistent improvements across different neural network architectures. One interesting phenomenon is that the improvements brought about by FedDecorr are much larger on wider networks (e.g., MobileNetV2, ResNet18) than on narrower ones (e.g. ResNet32). We conjecture this is because the dimension of the ambient space of wider networks are clearly higher than that of shallower networks. Therefore, relatively speaking, the dimensional collapse caused by data heterogeneity will be more severe for wider networks.
